history.content: Are you referring to the 45 Engineering Unit requirement?

children.subject: You should probably point out which requirement on the degree worksheet you're talking about... http://engineering.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/docs/eecs-worksheet-2014.pdf

Math does count as a "technical" unit (Technical courses are those in engineering, mathematics, chemistry, physics, statistics, biological sciences and computer science) but it is not an Engineering unit, so wouldn't count toward the 45... feel free to point out what requirement you mean so I can provide a more accurate answer. Thanks!

Yea I'm referring to the 45 engineering units. I can understand why math does not count as "technical". My point is that the definition of "technical" in EECS is inconsistent: CS majors can take Math 110 as one of their "7 units of Upper Division Technical Electives. So apparently Math 110 is technical there. http://www.eecs.berkeley.edu/csugrad/index.shtml#upperdiv

Additionally, I'm not referring to technicalities here; I'm referring to the logic/reasoning as to why this particular course can be taken by CS Majors for technical credit, but not by EECS majors for technical credit based on the content of the course. What was the reasoning behind the department's decision to make it this way? CS-based EECS majors follow a nearly identical track to CS majors, so this inconsistency doesn't make sense to me - I'm simply seeking for the logic behind it.

Hello- you may want to speak with ESS to learn more about this requirement. However, to clarify, math DOES count as a technical unit (toward one of your two techs/semester) however, EECS and CS have different requirements. The EECS requirement you're referring to is 45 Engineering units- which is different from the CS technical requirement. For Engineering units, the courses must be from engineering departments, of which math is not one. I hope this helps.
I'm not particularly sure; I'm referring to EECS technicals. That may be a part of the 45 engineering units - I'm not sure,

history.content: What is the reasoning behind Math 110 being able to be counted as an upper division technical for the CS major, but not for the EECS major? It seems linear algebra is valuable for both EE and CS, so I was just wondering why this is the case.
history.subject: Math 110
